record_data.record_plain_text: 5 1 YANKEE GAS SERVICES COMPANY STATEMENT OF OPERATING CONDITIONS FOR FIRM INTERSTATE TRANSPORTATION SERVICE DEFINITIONS Applicable Laws shall mean all applicable federal, state and local laws, ordinances, rules, regulations, orders, decrees or other duly authorized actions of any Governmental Authority having jurisdiction over the parties, the Transporter’s distribution facilities and/or the transactions under any service agreement for firm interstate transportation service. Authorized Overrun Service shall mean the service that enables Shipper to request volumes in excess of Shipper’s Maximum Daily Quantity, as provided for herein. British Thermal Unit or Btu shall mean the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of one pound of water one degree Fahrenheit at 60 degrees Fahrenheit. Daily Transportation Quantity shall mean the quantity of gas that Shipper nominates for delivery from the Receipt Point(s) to the Delivery Point on a particular Day. Day shall mean the 24-hour period commencing at ten o’clock (10:00) a.m. Eastern Clock Time, or such other hour as designated by the North American Energy Standards Board or any successor body. Dekatherm or DTH shall mean a quantity of heat equal to ten therms or one million British Thermal Units (one MMBtu). Delivery Point shall mean the point of interconnection between the facilities of Transporter and Shipper as may be more fully described in the service agreement. FERC shall mean the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission or its successor agency. Gas shall mean any mixture of hydrocarbons and non-combustible gases in a gaseous state consisting primarily of methane. Governmental Authority shall mean any federal, state, local or municipal governmental body, any governmental, regulatory or administrative agency, commission, body or other authority exercising or entitled to exercise any administrative, executive, judicial, legislative, policy, regulatory or taxing authority or power; or any court or governmental tribunal. Interstate Pipeline shall mean any interstate pipeline that is directly interconnected with Transporter such that it is able to deliver Gas to the Receipt Point(s). Maximum Daily Quantity or MDQ shall mean the maximum quantity of gas net of fuel loss which Transporter shall be obligated to transport and deliver in the aggregate from the Receipt Point(s) and deliver through Transporter’s distribution facilities to the Delivery Point. Receipt Point(s) shall mean the point(s) of interconnection between the facilities of Transporter and Interstate Pipeline as more full described in the service agreement. Shipper shall mean any entity entering into a Firm Interstate Transportation Service Agreement with Transporter to receive service in accordance with the terms and conditions set forth herein, or its successors or assigns. Transporter shall mean Yankee Gas Services Company, its successors or assigns. APPLICABILITY Transporter shall provide firm interstate transportation service by receiving Daily Transportation Quantities delivered by Shipper to the Receipt Point(s) and by redelivering such quantities, pursuant to the terms and conditions herein and as specified in the service agreement, to the Delivery Point. CHARGES For services provided, Shipper shall pay Transporter as follows: Demand Charge. Shipper shall pay Transporter a monthly demand charge not to exceed $1.45 per Ccf for the MDQ set out in the service agreement. Volumetric Charge. For volumes transported and delivered to Shipper at the Delivery Point, Shipper shall pay Transporter a volumetric charge not to exceed $0.1242 per Ccf for the first 2,500 Ccf per month, and not to exceed $0.0211 per Ccf for all volumes over 2,500 Ccf per month. Monthly Charges. Shipper shall pay a fixed monthly Customer Service Charge not to exceed $150.00 per month and a Daily Demand Meter Charge not to exceed $16.14 per month. GAS DELIVERIES The Maximum Daily Quantity of Gas that Transporter shall be obligated to transport and deliver on behalf of Shipper, on a firm basis, from the Receipt Point(s) to the Delivery Point shall be as forth in the service agreement, measured at the Delivery Point. Shipper may request on any day, pursuant to the Nomination section set forth below, overrun service in excess of Shipper’s MDQ (“Authorized Overrun Service”). Transporter may authorize the requested service by providing Shipper prior written consent when, in Transporter’s reasonable judgment, the capacity and operating capability of its system will accommodate such service without impairing Transporter’s ability to meet its other obligations; provided, however, Transporter shall have no “Supplier of Last Resort” obligation and no obligation to plan its system to serve Shipper’s loads. In addition to any charges incurred for services as provided under the Charges section herein: The daily rate for Authorized Overrun Service shall be the sum of the 100 percent load factor equivalent of the monthly Demand Charge divided by 30.4 plus the Volumetric Charge, as such charges are set forth under the Charges section herein. If, on any day, Shipper’s takes exceed its MDQ or the total service under Authorized Overrun Service without authorization, Shipper shall be assessed and shall pay a penalty of $25 per Dekatherm, plus the applicable daily spot price for “AGT Citygates” as published in Gas Daily, provided that Shipper’s unauthorized overrun was not caused by a malfunction of Transporter’s metering or regulator equipment. If Gas Daily no longer publishes an index for “AGT Citygates,” Transporter and Shipper shall agree upon a replacement index to be used. Daily Transportation Quantity Nominations. Shipper shall provide Transporter with prompt notice of Shipper’s Daily Transportation Quantity nominations to the Receipt Point(s) prior to any Day and shall conform to the nomination and confirmation deadlines of Interstate Pipeline. Daily Transportation Quantity nominations shall be considered first through the meter at the Receipt Point(s). Upon receiving nominations, Transporter shall receive such quantities at the Receipt Point(s) and redeliver such quantities, subject to the Lost and Unaccounted-for Gas section herein, to Shipper at the Delivery Point. Upstream Interstate Pipeline Transportation. It shall be Shipper’s responsibility to arrange with the Interstate Pipeline for the delivery of Shipper’s Gas to the Receipt Point(s). Shipper shall be responsible for any Interstate Pipeline imbalance charges, penalties, or other applicable charges incurred by, or applicable to, Shipper. Balancing. Shipper and Transporter shall make arrangements for the balancing of receipts and deliveries, including any arrangements to accommodate imbalances between Shipper and Interstate Pipeline. Shipper may change its Daily Gas nomination consistent with any intra-Day nomination changes permitted by Interstate Pipeline so long as Shipper provides Transporter with written or electronic notice of such changed nomination at least one hour prior to the applicable intra-Day nomination deadline permitted by Interstate Pipeline; provided, however, Transporter reserves the right to reject or modify any nomination not accepted or confirmed by Interstate Pipeline. Lost and Unaccounted-for Gas. Transporter shall reduce the quantity of Shipper’s Gas delivered by Interstate Pipeline by an amount equal to Transporter’s Unaccounted-for Gas percentage calculation for the current calendar year, which is based on the most recent five-year system average published and circulated to Shipper in the fourth quarter preceding the calendar year for which it will be in effect. Quality Specifications. Shipper shall meet the then-current quality specifications required by Interstate Pipeline. BILLING AND METERING Billing. Transporter shall render invoices for service rendered to Shipper by the fifteenth day of each month. Such invoices shall include a statement showing the amount due applicable to the preceding month, along with a computation of the amount due and payable. Payment. Shipper shall pay all invoices rendered for service within twenty-eight days of Shipper’s receipt of such invoices. Late Payment Charge; Billing Disputes. If Shipper does not pay an invoice within the time period provided herein, Transporter shall add a late payment charge equal to one percent of the unpaid invoice. At the end of each nominal twenty-eight day billing interval thereafter, Transporter may add an additional late payment charge equal to one percent of any unpaid amount. Should a dispute arise regarding the amount payable in any invoice rendered by Transporter, Shipper shall pay the undisputed amount and notify Transporter of any disputed amount in a timely to avoid assessment of Late Payment Charges on the disputed amount. If it is ultimately determined that Shipper owes all or some of the disputed amount, Shipper shall pay that amount plus interest equal to one percent of such amount per each nominal twenty-eight day billing interval during which such amount was owed to Transporter. Measurement. Transporter shall install meters as necessary to accurately and reliably measure the volumes of Gas delivered to Shipper in accordance with generally accepted industry practices. If the use of electronic or other types of flow computers is utilized, they shall be installed, and volumes shall be calculated, in accordance with generally accepted industry practices. Shipper may install, maintain, and operate at its own expense, such check measuring equipment as it desires, provided that such equipment shall be so installed so as not to interfere with the operation of Transporters’ facilities, including measuring equipment. Metering. Transporter shall make available to Shipper isolated secure connection points from Transporter’s metering equipment for Shipper, at Shipper’s sole expense, to receive electronic signals providing pressure, flow rates, and total usage. Transporter shall also provide Shipper, on a commercially reasonable basis, a daily usage report showing actual deliveries of Gas to the Delivery Point for billing purposes. Such daily usage reports shall reflect a two-day calendar lag in information due to the download of metering data to the report. If there are any differences between the electronic meter information, Shipper and Transporter will accept the daily usage report as the document that will govern as to monthly billing information. FORCE MAJEURE The term “Force Majeure” shall mean any unforeseeable cause beyond the reasonable control of the party claiming Force Majeure, which by exercise of due foresight such party could not reasonably have been expected to avoid and which, by the exercise of due diligence, it is unable to overcome, including, but not limited to: acts of God; acts of a public enemy; expropriation or confiscation of facilities; acts of declared or undeclared war; acts of terrorism; public disorder; rebellion or sabotage; revolution, epidemic; landslide; lightning; fire; hurricane; earthquake; flood; riot; explosion; partial or entire failure of utilities; breakage or accident to gas transportation or distribution facilities or equipment or lines of pipe, freezing of wells or pipelines; strikes; work stoppage associated with a labor dispute; injunction or quarantine; changes in Applicable Laws subsequent to the Effective Date hereof; or action or inaction by any Governmental Authority. Except for Shipper’s obligation to make payments under a service agreement, the parties shall be excused from performing their respective obligations under such service agreement and shall not be liable in damages or otherwise if and to the extent that they are unable to so perform or are prevented from performing by Force Majeure, provided that: the non-performing party, as promptly as practicable after the occurrence of the Force Majeure, gives the other party written notice describing the particulars of the occurrence; in the event the Force Majeure outage would cause Transporter to be unable to transport supply for the current or next Gas Day, Transporter will notify Shipper by phone as soon as practicable; the suspension of performance is of no greater scope and of no longer duration than is reasonably required by the Force Majeure; the non-performing party uses all reasonable efforts to remedy its inability to perform; and as soon as the non-performing party is able to resume performance of its obligations hereunder, it gives prompt written notice thereof to the other party. CURTAILMENT To the extent that Transporter’s facilities are unable on any Day, by reason of Force Majeure or otherwise, to provide delivery to meet Shipper’s Daily Transportation Quantity, Transporter’s interruptible customers shall first be curtailed. After all of Transporter’s interruptible customers have been curtailed, Shipper’s Daily Transportation Quantity shall, if necessary, be curtailed on a pro rata basis with Transporter’s other firm obligations at the affected Receipt Point(s).
record_data.filing_title: Yankee Gas Services Company, Baseline Filing of Statement of Operating Condition
